data.title: Wrong keyboard or shortcuts after starting VScode ?
data.body:
Hello !

Sometimes (not systematic), when I start VS code, when I do a Ctrl+Z (undo) shortcut on my AZERTY keyboard, it is interpreted as a Ctrl+W (close tab).

I think there is an error on the keyboard mapping on shortcuts which will be as QWERTY.
There is no problems with my code, which is correctly writen with AZERTY keyboard.

My solution to fix it is to close and re-open VS code.

System informations :
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.12.3-1-ARCH (installed [AUR visual-studio-code](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/visual-studio-code))
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-rust|kal|0.4.2
vue|liu|0.1.5
Go|luk|0.6.63
vetur|oct|0.9.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0

I can't find a way to reproduce systematically the problem, sorry :-/
If you have an idea, i'll try !

Thank you !

data.title: [Debug] Continue one thread will cause other threads' stack frames lost in CallStack panel when debugging multi-threads
data.body:
- VSCode Version: VSCode 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

We're developing java debugger, and found that VSCode debug panel will lose some threads' call stacks  for multi-threads case.

See the screenshot below. There are two breakpoints hitted simultaneously by different threads (Thread-0 and Thread-1), and VSCode CallStack panel could display their call stacks correctly. (Note: When the breakpoint was hitted, i send a StoppedEvent with flag allThreadsStopped=false)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14052197/28860267-76f9cecc-778e-11e7-94a1-e8e20520c433.png)

Then i choose to continue Thread-0 (threadId is 444) first. Thread-0 completed as expected. But Thread-1's call stacks are lost in VSCode CallStack panel. The whole debug process hanging there. See the screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14052197/28860526-9b03293e-778f-11e7-8160-d59a542f4f47.png)
Below are the DA requests and responses after the continue operation.
[REQUEST]
{"command":"continue","arguments":{"threadId":444},"type":"request","seq":18}
[[RESPONSE]]
{"success":true,"request_seq":18,"command":"continue","body":{"allThreadsContinued":false},"seq":28,"type":"response"}
[[RESPONSE]]
{"event":"thread","body":{"reason":"exited","threadId":444,"type":"thread"},"seq":29,"type":"event"}

[Expected]:
Because Thread-1 is still suspended by breakpoint, VSCode is supposed to keep Thread-1's call stacks after Thread-0 continued and terminated.

data.title: Be proactive about defending against unauthorized telemetry collection
data.body:
In the past couple of weeks we've seen plugins in two popular editors taken over by a commercial entity, who has then added seemingly identifiable telemetry collection to those plugins:

- Atom (atom-minimap and autocomplete-python): https://github.com/atom-minimap/minimap/issues/588, summary: https://theoutline.com/post/1953/how-a-vc-funded-company-is-undermining-the-open-source-community
> Back to autocomplete-python. A number of developers who reviewed the tool found that the changes Kite made were far more invasive than what it had done to Minimap. The new version of autocomplete-python demoted the open source engine it had been using, called Jedi, and enabled Kites engine by default.
> 
> Kites engine required code be processed on Kites cloud server, while the previous version did this work on the users machine. This is a crucial difference because sending data to the cloud is a privacy issue, especially given the wide-ranging access permission requested by the tool. Developers said they worried that various scenarios could lead to medical data, payment data, and other data that should be kept private being uploaded to Kite. Furthermore, many private companies have policies against uploading data to third parties, which would make Kite unusable for developers at those companies.

- Sublime Text (SideBarEnhancements package): https://forum.sublimetext.com/t/rfc-default-package-control-channel-and-package-telemetry/30157, summary: https://www.reddit.com/r/programming/comments/6qwtfz/kite_injected_telemetry_into_the_third_most/dl0psv0/

With the revelation that this has not been limited to one editor, I think it's important that Visual Studio Code implements a proactive policy to either scan uploaded extensions for telemetry collection or sandbox extensions with a permissions system similar to Chrome Extensions / WebExtensions.

I realise that this is a significant undertaking, but with what's come to light in recent weeks, there's a non-zero chance that this is occurring in Visual Studio extensions as well, without user knowledge.

data.title: TS Version Selector does not update path and label from user settings
data.body:
Testing #31785

1. Set `typescript.tsdk` to an invalid path in user settings (I set it to `"typescript.tsdk": "potato"`). An error message is shown when selected and we fall back to the bundled ts version
2. Run `npm install typescript`. Version selector now has two entries
3. Remove user setting and revert `typescript.tsdk` to null.

The version selector still contains the old invalid path and label, even when the user setting is deleted or updated to match the default. Also occurs even if local TS is not installed.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7109548/28855859-568df4b4-76f4-11e7-8cb6-9bc33c9f565e.png)

data.title: FileSystemWatcher API to handle changes to files.exclude?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
From:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31825
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31822

**Problem**
The `tsconfig.json` build task provider currently detects `tsconfig.json` files in the workspace using `findFiles` on first run and then using a `FileSystemWatcher` after wards to keep the list of  `tsconfig.json` up to date. This approach does not handle changes to `files.exclude` properly.

My current workaround is to only rely on `findFiles` to pick up the configs. I'm not sure if this will cause performance issues for very large workspaces for users on HDDs compared to the mixed find and watcher approach.

**Questions**
- Will `findFiles` be fast enough on its own for this scenario? I've done basic testing and it seems quick
- Would there be any other extensions that could benefit from understanding when a file is excluded or included? Should there be an official API for this?

data.title: Git clone dialog: right arrow doesn't deselect text
data.body:
- "Git: Clone" command
- Enter some git url, press enter
- Another quickopen is opened with the text prepopulated with my home dir. The text is selected.
- Press right arrow key
- Nothing happens
- I expect it to deselect text and put the cursor on the right

- If I press the left arrow key, it deselects and puts the cursor on the left

I'm guessing this is related to the feature in quickopen where it opens the selected file in the background when you press the right arrow key. But that isn't relevant here, so it seems like it should be disabled, since it makes it hard to add a subfolder to that text. Also reproes in command palette.

`"git.defaultCloneDirectory": "~/GitHub"`

2. checkout repository

1. git clone to home directory/GitHub
2. proper opening of folder/project w/ VSC

Actual result:

1. checkout goes to the ether somewhere
2. when saying 'OK' to open the project an error appears saying "/~/GitHub" does not exist (which, of course, it shouldn't)

Regression:

The main reason I'm doing this is because I like to share my settings across machines where each has a different users directory (e.g., `/usr/flip` on unix boxes, `/Users/flip` on macOS, etc.

Alternately, some sort of HOME directory token might make sense? $HOME or some such?
